Modals

Ian Lyttle

2016-12-10

library("htmltools")
library("bsplus")
bs_modal(id = "modal", title = "I'm a modal", body = "Yes, I am.")

I'm a modal

Yes, I am.
tags$button(type = "button", class = "btn btn-default", "Click for modal") %>%
  bs_attach_modal(id_modal = "modal")
bs_modal(
  id = "modal_markdown", 
  title = "Using Markdown",
  body = render_html_fragment(
    system.file("markdown", "modal.md", package = "bsplus")
  )
)
## /Applications/RStudio.app/Contents/MacOS/pandoc/pandoc +RTS -K512m -RTS modal.utf8.md --to html --from markdown+autolink_bare_uris+ascii_identifiers+tex_math_single_backslash --output /var/folders/rg/9kvy_lsn43z90d439n02nfw80000gn/T//RtmpjgBIRw/file9e5865ff7e09 --smart --email-obfuscation none --self-contained --mathjax --standalone --section-divs --template /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/3.3/Resources/library/rmarkdown/rmd/fragment/default.html --no-highlight
## 
## Output created: /var/folders/rg/9kvy_lsn43z90d439n02nfw80000gn/T//RtmpjgBIRw/file9e5865ff7e09

Using Markdown

4th-level headers work well

We can do our regular Markdown stuff in modal windows.

  • \(F = ma\)
  • \(E = mc^2\)
tags$button(type = "button", class = "btn btn-default", "Click for modal") %>%
  bs_attach_modal(id_modal = "modal_markdown")
